awd_titl_txt: Toolkit for Characterizing Noisy Quantum Processors and Windows of Quantum Advantage
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum computers offer potential advantages and possibly exponential speedup over existing classical computers for certain computational tasks. Success in building large-scale functioning quantum computers will undoubtedly be a revolution in computer technology. However, many of these applications will require quantum computers with very small error rates and which use quantum error corrections for tolerating faults - a technology that is still out of reach for near-term noisy devices.  Nevertheless, there are certain tasks that near-term quantum processors can perform but are still difficult for the current best classical computers. The demonstration of a quantum advantage will first require development of tools characterizing the operation of quantum gates, state preparation and measurement, as well as the corresponding errors. This project will integrate these tools to streamline their use in cloud quantum computers. Understanding the noise and errors also helps to devise mitigation strategies so as to extract as much as possible the correct computation. This project will also employ classical simulations to compare the expected outcomes with runs on quantum computers and analyze schemes for demonstrating potential quantum advantages.

The goal of this project is to develop and assemble a toolkit for near-term quantum information processing that may yield quantum advantage.  In particular, the PI will design and integrate tools for  (1) noisy-gate characterization of tomographic tools, (2) randomized benchmarking, (3) error mitigation methods. These will be tested in actual runs on cloud quantum computers. Furthermore, (4) classical simulations will be developed,  such as tensor-network methods, for noisy quantum circuits, and (5) schemes for quantum supremacy via short-depth quantum circuits will be assessed. Other new schemes will also be explored that will provide  alternative playgrounds for showing the advantages of quantum devices over classical ones. Developing a toolkit that consists of technical approaches and software building will help to verify intermediate-scale noisy quantum information processing and identify windows of parameters guiding towards demonstrating quantum advantage. This project will also involve training of graduate students in research activities, presentation and writing skills, and mentoring in career planning. It will provide undergraduates and high-school students some first-hand experience in quantum information science (QIS) research.  The PI will work with his colleagues to develop a quantum information science/quantum technology track in the Master's program in the Department of Physics and Astronomy. Creation of such a QIS track/program will help steadily train a quantum-smart workforce that is projected to be of high demand in the United States in the next few decades.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum computing exploits quantum-mechanical properties, such as superposition, entanglement, and unitary evolution, to perform computational tasks, and for some problems, it theoretically provides substantial speedup against classical counterparts. The field progressed from theoretical consideration to emergence of actual yet noisy quantum processors with hundreds of qubits. Fault-tolerant computation requires error correction, which may be decades away. How can we utilize near-term quantum processors, despite them being noisy and error-prone, and progress towards quantum advantage?

The intellectual merits of this project are to develop and integrate tools for error mitigation to enhance noisy processors’ performance and for benchmarking their performance via comparing classical simulations with cloud experiments. Additionally, it aims to analyze algorithms that may achieve quantum advantage. Several outcomes are highlighted below.

The PI and collaborators employed the so-called detector tomography to characterize accuracy of quantum processors’ output, obtaining good characterization for readout. With this, they proposed a mitigation method, allowing to infer perfect readout distribution despite imperfect measurement, which has become a standard technique in, e.g., IBM's Qiskit. The PI’s team also developed methods to mitigate gate errors and improved zero-noise extrapolation by utilizing a reference state to measure the system’s total energy. They applied these to simulating ground (or lowest-energy) states of large quantum spin-chains (specifically Heisenberg and XXZ models), using up to 102 qubits. They also employed numerical tensor-network tools to compare experimental results, which were accurate up to a few percent. Their work was featured in an IBM’s blog (entitled "You need 100 qubits to accelerate discovery with quantum") and was among the first to utilize 100+ qubits. 

In another direction, the PI and collaborators utilized methods to diagonalize eigenstates (energy-levels) of a disordered model with fermions (which don’t like to occupy same states). They identified how behavior of entanglement changes as the disorder strength increases. The PI and collaborators studied interacting bosons (opposite to fermions) on one-dimensional lattice and could solve eigenstates exactly for two-boson sectors, finding particles called doublons, formed by two bosons occupying same or nearby sites despite strong repulsion. These can be simulated on digital quantum computers or analog quantum simulators. 

In measurement-based quantum computation (MBQC), computation proceeds by sequentially measuring spins locally that were initially in some entangled state. An important issue is whether these emerge as ground states of short-ranged interacting Hamiltonians possessing a finite energy gap. The PI and collaborators previously identified the so-called Affleck-Kennedy-Lieb-Tasaki (AKLT) Hamiltonians, whose ground states provide quantum-computational power.  However, there was a three-decade outstanding problem whether the Hamiltonian contains a finite energy gap, as this would allow the resource state to be created by cooling to sufficiently low temperatures. The PI and his student employed both analytic and tensor-network methods to rigorously prove this. They also extended results to other AKLT models, including in three dimensions. These link quantum spin systems to the utility of quantum computation.

Towards algorithmic schemes, the PI and his student developed a procedure that uses ancillary qubits coupling to the system and then measures ancillas one by one; this results in the system projected to eigenstates and can serve as a subroutine to obtain the ground state of another complicated Hamiltonian by connecting it to a simple one. The PI and another student applied this to finding energy potentials for simple molecules, such as H2O. In a different direction, the PI and collaborators analyzed whether quantum algorithms could expediate problem solving in geometry and topology and developed a quantum algorithm determining whether a given closed curve on a closed manifold can be shrunk to a point continuously. It performs exponentially faster than known classical methods, providing quantum advantage.

In terms of broader impact, the PI had provided scientific training to several undergraduate and graduate students and supported some to attend summer schools, workshops, and conferences. He trained their presentation skills and gave them career advice. Two PhD students completed dissertations and continued with research positions. The PI also provided students opportunities to engage in outreach with high-school students.

The PI led the effort in creating a MSc program in Quantum Information Science and Technology at Stony Brook University. In developing a new QIS course, he recorded 25 lectures during the pandemic and posted them to YouTube (links available on his website), and the videos had accumulated a few thousand views, reaching beyond the original class of twenty-one, with international viewers aged 18-65. Lecture notes were available on his course website.

He gave a talk at the 2022 IBM Quantum Educator Summit, discussing aspects of teaching QIS, and was a panelist at an IBM's Qiskit Quantum Seminar, discussing prospects of utilizing quantum computers of 100+ qubits. One student made her codes of Clifford sampling available on Github; the PI wrote a review article on MBQC and a book chapter on AKLT models. These serve as resources for students and researchers.
